All textiles, and parts of textiles, including decoration and accessories and the like, must be produced according to Standard 100 by OEKO-TEX and comply with JYSK OEKO-TEX requirements in General Requirements, and the limits in the relevant product classes in Annex 4 and 6.

Note: JYSK will randomly test up against these limits for all types of products containing textiles.

All products containing textiles must be labelled and marked to comply with Regulation (EU) No 1007/2011 in accordance with JYSK’s instructions and JYSK 6004.

Use of the designation “other fibres” according to Article 9(2) must be approved by JYSK C&Q before first application.

Use of the designation “mixed fibres” or “unspecified textile composition” according to Article 9(4) must be approved by JYSK C&Q before first application.

Use of the designation "Contains non-textile parts of animal origin" according to Article 12 must be approved by JYSK C&Q before first application.

Textile products sold as Personal Protective Equipment, such as pot holders, oven- and barbeque gloves, garden gloves must comply with requirements regarding The Personal Protective Equipment Regulation (PPE) in accordance with JYSK General Requirements.

Page 3/11

Edition 8 – 2024-07 Compliancequality@JYSK.com

The fiber composition must be specified in % using whole numbers for all textile components. Note: Do not apply percentages to non-fiber materials! - See ‘Example 4’ in 4.1.

Specified compositions must comply with Table 1.

Page 4/11

Products containing textiles must comply with the textile quality requirements stated in JYSK standards or stated by the Category Manager (CAM).

Suppliers must provide a copy of test reports if required by JYSK. Note: JYSK will randomly test up against the quality requirements.

Samples must be prepared for testing according to ISO 139.

If no textile quality requirements are stated in JYSK standards or stated by CAM products containing textile must comply with Table 2.

Page 6/11

Measure according to the procedure for flat made-up articles in ISO 3759.

For round/circular items measure the diameter instead of overall length and overall width.

Measure according to the procedure for flat made-up articles in ISO 3759 under a tension of 5 Newton to remove wrinkles and bulges.

The overall length and overall width must be measured in three evenly distributed locations.

Procedure for modified method:

• Make a regular measurement without tension (according to 6.1.1) before starting the modified procedure.

• The clamping method used to apply tension must trap as little fabric as possible.

• Tension must be applied slowly and not exceed the specified tension value at any time.

• Measurements must be taken within one minute after tension has been applied.

• The mattress pad must not be stretched excessively prior to application of tension.

Fixed end

Tensioned end

Measure according to the procedure for garments in ISO 3759.

JYSK STANDARD Textile requirements
This standard describes JYSK requirements for textiles.
Section Changes 3 Added chapter about textile products sold as Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). 6.16 Absorbency description is also valid for tea towels.
Edition 8 – 2024-07 Compliancequality@JYSK.com
Edition 8 – 2024-07 Compliancequality@JYSK.com
1 Chemical contents in textiles

All textiles, and parts of textiles, including decoration and accessories and the like, must be produced according to Standard 100 by OEKO-TEX and comply with JYSK OEKO-TEX requirements in General Requirements, and the limits in the relevant product classes in Annex 4 and 6.
Note: JYSK will randomly test up against these limits for all types of products containing textiles.
2 Labelling and marking of fibre composition
All products containing textiles must be labelled and marked to comply with Regulation (EU) No 1007/2011 in accordance with JYSK’s instructions and JYSK 6004.
2.1 Use of “other fibres” designation
Use of the designation “other fibres” according to Article 9(2) must be approved by JYSK C&Q before first application.
2.2 Use of “mixed fibres” designation
Use of the designation “mixed fibres” or “unspecified textile composition” according to Article 9(4) must be approved by JYSK C&Q before first application.
2.3 Use of "non-textile parts of animal origin"
Use of the designation "Contains non-textile parts of animal origin" according to Article 12 must be approved by JYSK C&Q before first application.
3 Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)

Textile products sold as Personal Protective Equipment, such as pot holders, oven- and barbeque gloves, garden gloves must comply with requirements regarding The Personal Protective Equipment Regulation (PPE) in accordance with JYSK General Requirements.
Edition 8 – 2024-07 Compliancequality@JYSK.com
4 Fiber composition tolerances
The fiber composition must be specified in % using whole numbers for all textile components. Note: Do not apply percentages to non-fiber materials! - See ‘Example 4’ in 4.1.
Specified compositions must comply with Table 1.
Specified content Tolerance Test method ≥6% ±3,0% 5% ±2,5% 4% ±2,0% ISO/TR 11827 3% ±1,5% and 2% ±1,0% ISO 1833 1% ±0,5% series 100% (Pure fibre) ±0% (Virgin material) +0%/-0,5% (Recycled material)
Table 1 – Tolerances to specified composition
4.1 Tolerance examples (Informative only)
Specified content Tolerated contents Cotton: 77% to 83% (80±3,0%) 80% Cotton / 20% Polyester Polyester: 17% to 23% (20±3,0%)
Specified content Tolerated contents 98% Cotton / 2% Elastane Cotton: 97% to 99% The cotton is de-facto subject to the ±1,0% tolerance of the Elastane. Elastane: 1% to 3% (2±1,0%)
Specified content Tolerated contents 80% Polyester / Polyester: 77% to 83% (80±3,0%) 15% Polypropylene / Polypropylene: 12% to 18% (15±3,0%) 5% Viscose Viscose: 2,5% to 7,5% (5±2,5%) Example 3
Specified content Tolerated contents Main surface: 100% Polyester Polyester: 100% (100±0%) (Virgin material) Backing: Latex Latex Fiber tolerance does not apply as the material is not in fiber form.
Example 4 - A virgin polyester bath mat with latex backing
Edition 8 – 2024-07 Compliancequality@JYSK.com
5 Textile Quality Requirements
Products containing textiles must comply with the textile quality requirements stated in JYSK standards or stated by the Category Manager (CAM).
Suppliers must provide a copy of test reports if required by JYSK. Note: JYSK will randomly test up against the quality requirements.
Samples must be prepared for testing according to ISO 139.
5.2 General textile quality requirements
If no textile quality requirements are stated in JYSK standards or stated by CAM products containing textile must comply with Table 2.

Requirement: Test method: Before washing (original) e z i +5%/0% According to 6.1 S After washing and drying +5%/-5% GSM / Weight Agreed specification +10%/-5% According to 6.2 Yarn count Agreed specification ±5% According to 6.3 Thread count Agreed specification ±2% According to 6.4 Tensile strength ≥Agreed specification According to 6.5 Tear strength ≥Agreed specification According to 6.6 Woven fabrics: ≥3-4 Pilling Knitted fabrics: Natural fibres: Man-made fibres: ≥3-4 Filament yarns: ≥3-4 Staple yarns: ≥3 According to 6.7 Water ≥3 (≥3-4 for OEKO-TEX product class I) According to 6.8 Acidic perspiration ≥3-4 According to 6.9 : Alkaline perspiration ≥3-4 According to 6.9 s s e n t s Rubbing Dry: ≥4 Wet: ≥3-4 According to 6.10 a f r Saliva and perspiration Baby: Fast LMBG 82.10-1 o l o Light ≥3-4 According to 6.11 C Washing (As applicable) ≥3-4 According to 6.12 Dry cleaning (As applicable) ≥3-4 According to 6.13 Ironing (As applicable) ≥3-4 ISO 105 X11 Ignitability Must comply with specified requirement According to 6.14
Table 2 – General textile quality requirements
Edition 8 – 2024-07 Compliancequality@JYSK.com
6.1 Size and dimensional stability to washing and drying
Measure the product in original condition and again after washing and drying according to ISO 6330.

Configuration of ISO 6330 Washing machine type Type A Washing and drying procedure According to specified for the product Detergent Non-phosphate reference detergent 3 (ECE reference detergent 98 without optical brightener)

Assessment methods of different products Product type Measurement method Tolerance % of nominal size specification: Flat made-up article according to 6.1.1 𝑥𝑚 − 𝑥𝑛 𝑥𝑛 ∙ 100 Mattress pads according to 6.1.2 Where: 𝑥𝑛 is the nominal dimension 𝑥𝑚is the measured dimension Initial size: According to tolerances stated in specification for product (e.g. measurement point diagram or made up instruction) Complicated textile products Size after washing and drying: e.g.: • Clothes / Garments • Products specified according to according to 6.1.3 Maximum dimensional change in %: 𝑥𝑡 − 𝑥𝑜 𝑥𝑜 ∙ 100 measurement point diagram Where: 𝑥𝑜 is the nominal dimension 𝑥𝑡is the measured dimension (Note: same as ISO 5077)
Edition 8 – 2024-07 Compliancequality@JYSK.com
6.1.1 Measurement method - Flat made-up article
Measure according to the procedure for flat made-up articles in ISO 3759.
For round/circular items measure the diameter instead of overall length and overall width.
6.1.2 Measurement method - Mattress pads
Measure according to the procedure for flat made-up articles in ISO 3759 under a tension of 5 Newton to remove wrinkles and bulges.
The overall length and overall width must be measured in three evenly distributed locations.
Procedure for modified method:
• Make a regular measurement without tension (according to 6.1.1) before starting the modified procedure.
• The clamping method used to apply tension must trap as little fabric as possible.
• Tension must be applied slowly and not exceed the specified tension value at any time.
• Measurements must be taken within one minute after tension has been applied.
• The mattress pad must not be stretched excessively prior to application of tension.
Photo-examples of modified setup
MOU oo Wu OL te peepee a Sl
6.1.3 Measurement method - Complicated products
Measure according to the procedure for garments in ISO 3759.
